div.head: PLAGUE IN BARRACKS. ENGLISH EX-SOLDIER SUCCUMBS.
div.p: A death from plague Em occnrred at Masta-pba I'a<h» barracks, Alexandria, whore the 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers aro stationed.

The victim's name is Wilky, a man of 32 yoars, who was formerly a private in the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire!, and bad been for the last three years employed as assistant io the grocery bar at Mustapha canteen.

The doceased had only been ill for threo days, first showing suspicions symptoms on Wednesday last and expiring on Satarday in hospital, shortly after being admitted. His foneral took plaoe yesterday morning, the deceased being accorded tbo nsnal military honoors. Three hundred men of the Dublin Fosiliers and representatives of tho Departmental Corps accompanied the body to its last resting place at tbo British oemetery, where tbo bnrial service was to id by the Roy. A. Longley.

The qoarters occupied by tbo deceased have been thoroughly disinfeo»od, and every precaution has been tiken by the military author ities to prevent an extension of the disease. A tent has been erected on a waste piece of land near the sea where the other men employed in the grocery bar have been iso'a'ed and aro medically examined lonr times a day.

div.head:
Cairo In Winter
PROSPECTS OF THE SOICAL SEASON
div.p: At in other years, the feast of Beyram strikes the first chorda of the opening chorea of the Cairo "Season j" and judging from the signs ot the times thia winter bids lair to be a greater aacooss than its predecessor. Indeed, Cairo baa already shaken the summer sleep Irom its eyes and on every aide preparations are being made to welcome back the expected guesti and to attraot the new ones. Nearly all the well known roaidonta have onoo more returned to their comfortable quarters, and each day seer mure lamiliar faces io tho streets.

Changes thero are in plenty. New baildings have sprung up like mushrooms einoe the spring, and alterations surronnd one on evtry •ide. The new 8emiramis Hotel on the river bank baa already attained gigantio site, and though etill tar from being complete, it' promises to be habitable before the winter is half over. Tho extension of the Savoy is still in the bands of the builder, but much will be done in tho next few weeks, and the devoted patrons of this most favoured hotel need have no fear that their'oomfort will suffer in any way after its dours are onoe opened.

The improvements at Sbepheard't have already been enlarged upon in these oolumns.The additions reflect the greatest oredit on those who are responsible for them, and add fresh loitre to the historio house. The band which plays there on 8atnrdsy afternoons add, considerably to its popularity, and even tho* early io the season it is difficult to find an empty tea-table during the length of the programme.
Modarn Ghezireh.

Ghezireh is fast becoming an enormons suburb of handsome villas ; new roads are being oat in all directions, and even the gorgeous gardens of the Ubetireh Palaoe Hotel have been requisitioned by the ever spreading com-moDity. There be many who lament the ruthless destruction of this beautiful lung of Cairo, but such valaable property could hardly be exported to remain intact New regulations restriotieg the traffic through the grounds of the Sporliug Club have come into force this week ; and in fatare we hover like houris shot oat from Paradise unless we bear oar magic badges conspiououi on our persons. These precautions have doubtless been proved necessary, and are conducive to all those who have a claim upon the clnb, but a certain portion of the community is none too well pleased at the restriction.

It is early days to dilate upon the social events of ths future, but everything points to there being a plethora of eutertainments before many weeks are over. Both Shepheard's and the Mena Home Hotels have started with very successful small dance,; and the visit of Mme Jane Hading to the Theatre Abbas this week ooght to prove a great attraction. The first Skye meeting is dated for the 30th, and alter that we may expert the osbal rash of engagements and festivities which make Cairo what it is—the finest winter playground in the world.

div.head:
EMPIRE GROWN COTTON
SUCCESS OF EGYPTIAN VARIETIES
div.p: The ooancil of the British Cotton-growing Association, in their second annnal report, express themaelve* as strorgly of opinion that the time (or mere experiments has passed, and that tbo oase is proved. "All the ootton Lancashire require*," they say, 'can be grown within the limits of the Empire." The loss on the year's working amounts to £19.414 6a. 9*., bat this is shown to be a relative improvement of £15,834 17s. 6d. on last year's result, and the ooancil hope to reduce the loss still farther 1907, and by 1903 to show an oven acoount or posaibly a profit. Meanwhile an argent appeal is made for more capital.

The accounts for the work in Lagos show a profit of £9.489 4 a. 5J., this being equal, after the payment of all expenses, including depto-oiation and a proportion of the home expenditure, to a net surplos of £305 10«. 9d. It is hoped that next year Northern Nigeria and the Gold Coast will also prove a son roe of inoome. The total oapital of the association at present is £217 273, and the whole of the proposed capital—£500,000—will be required I very shortly.

The work aooompli«hed in the various Colonies is reviewed in the report Io the West Indies good progress hu been made, while West Alrioa as a whole has exceeded expectation*, some disappointment as regards Sierra Leone being more than compensated for by the results shown by the Gold Coast and Lagos.
"Hugo Poaalbllltlaa.

The results in Soatbsrn Nigeria have been disappointing, and io Northern Nigeria, which is described as having "hngc possibilities aa the great ootton field of the futore," the "main hopes of the association are oentred." In British Central Afriot the crop was to a great extent a lailnre. A beginning has been made British Bast Afr'ot, and the association ia al»b at work, either direotly or through other agencies, in Uganda, Rhodesia, South Africa, and E-ypt.

Dealing with the experiments in India arith Egyptian yarn, the report state,: It is now practically established that Egyptian oottoo be eoooMsfully grown in India, and as fully 1,000,000 acres are available, provided irrigation works are carried ont, the Association can confidently look to Sind to supplement the Egyptian cotton orop.
The onltivation of long-stapled ootton in Ceylon is making great progres*. Shipments of Egyptian cotton have realised 9jd. per poond and Sea Island ootton has been sold at le. per ponnd.
In E*,t Africa also Egyptian seed has been □sod with good results.

A repreieutative sent to British Bast Africa is stated to have reported most favoarably ol the prospects of an immediate and large extension of ootton cultivation there. The quality prodnood is of the Egyptian type, and is exceedingly good.

div.head: PAN ISLAMISM IN EGYPT.
div.p: The letter which we publish below wss received some time ago by "Al Mokattam," and is an interesting proof that:
1. Despite all the dementia of the Nationalist Press, Pan-blamism was preached, and vigorously preached, daring the past summer ;
2. That there are Egyptian Moslems who have the intelligence to comprehend the dangers of a propaganda ot di,integration and the eoarage to oppose it pnblio'y :
To the Editors of "Al Mokattam."
Kindly publish the following nnder my •igna'nre.

There has been ranch talk lately about tbs charge ot fanaticism miadqageiiut ns by Sir B. Grey and abont Pan-Islamism.rTbe Egyptians know nothing of fanatiobm tbtey are known' for their character. The charge fallstm the news-docile papers t hataroshboting for Pan Islami'tn and which gave to this word a political meaning before Eorope This Pan Islamism ha* brought »n sorts of trouble upon as. Ws Egyptians have nothing to do with politics and we make no dfitinetion between Christians and Mobs-Sedan*. jb papers that preach Pan-Islami*m.! Has there ever been a time when all Mohamedans ' wire nnder nne government siooe the day, of Moawiya I We have gained nothing by ibis polioy of yours. If yon do not stop here, we •hall lose what authority we have now, and the Government will not listen to as ia fetare.

O ye papers that preach Pan-Islamism ' Why preach patriotism I Yon ahonld try to make primary education general ; yon should innnd high schools where the young men will be taught patriotism and independence—not making any diatinetion between Christians and Mohamedans. Why do yon oot try to separate Egypt from Turkey and pay the tribute given to the lat'er for education T Doe, Tarkey spend Ibis tribute In defending as when it waa only yesterday that we were almost going to war with her for some land in Sinaj I Doeeshe spend the money in guarding the ronte of the Ei'grims—you know how mnoh we aoff*r at the ands of ths Governors in Arabi*. If yon are patrio'io yon should preach patriotism Then we may hope to have a representative body, and detach Bgypt from Turkey.
Abdel Mo'ti Hussein.
Omda of Samaleh, Peooas, Charkia.

div.head:
ZIZINIA THEATRE
"LE MAITRE DE FORGES"
div.p: George, Oboet'i "Msl're de Forge*" dors oot belong solely to the 19th end 29th centurio,; it is e pley for ell time We can picture some Cougreve or Utway treatiug the snbjeot nnder some snch style as "Pride for Pride"; Shakespeare might have resuscitated in its favour the old title of "Love's labour Woo," while the theme it one roond which Boccaccio might well have woven one of his romanoe*. May be it is the very romance, adaptable to all afci, which makes the play to a oertain ex'ent ontrne to life. What thinking womir, sach aa Claire, would, by coopting her husband's deeds to his word*, have for a moment doubted the continuity of his love 1 Wbat intelligent man, ol Philippe's stamp, whoso love, thoogh selfdenying, mast have ever been on the lookout for a spark of sympathy, coaid have so long remained blind to the change in his wife's affections ; the more so, as Claire mikes no attempt to nae the liberty, granted her by hatband on his lrnrning her love for the Dao de Blignj! Pride, and especially wounded prido, is blinder even than love Claire de Beaulien, whom de Bligny forsakes to marry the rich bonrgeoite, hud accepted purely ont of plque the hand of Philippe Derblay, a wealthy iron master and at the same time a preox chevalier, whose birth and calling are sank bsneeth his magna-Dimons temperament and exquisite delioaoy of mind. Claire's unreasoning love for de Bligny no less than hor pride of cato at first breeds repugnance for Philippe, which by degrees passes to gratitude, admiration, end finally to live for the man who is ready to make every sacrifice for her. This denodemeot is enhsnred by melodramatically logging in a due1, which affords Claire an opportunity for provirg her devotion to Philippe by throwing hertell between the two combatant,; the is wounded by the Dao's ballet, bat happily survives. Haart-randlng Plotura. There can be little donbt that of all the plays Mme Jane Hading has presented daring the past week, none have given the great artist more scope for the display of her eossnmmate talents than last Satorday's performance, which was throughout a heart-rending piotnre of remorse and "Weltschmerx." Un'.tkely as was the duel *0000, or rather the circumstances giving rise to it, its omission wonld have robbed nt of one of the finest scenes in Mme Hading's repertoire. In Act IV. to. I, her distress, her sobbing avowal of love, her attempta to stop the dnel, and her final resolve to save her hatband, were inimitably rendered, and left her audience spell bound and tearful. M. Arnand again proved bimrelf endowed] with no small dramat'o gifts. His Philippe Derb'ay wa, exaoily what it onght to be: dignified and sympathetic, mariter in modu, \fortir«rin'rt, and won the cordial approval of the hoose. It should be said that when neither he nor Mme Hading were "on," the interest was greatly impairel, there being nothing markworthy in the minor characters to help ont a rather thin dialogue.

"LA PETITE MABQU8IB" Yesterday Mme Hading gave her last performance prior to her departure for Cairo. 'I he play, we are sorry to say, was not happily chosen end, although it was a pleasure to witness Mme {lading's talents in the lighter vein, it is to be regretted that she found no better piece in which to display them. "La Petite Marquise" was preceded by the onrtsun-raiser "Tieh-Tio." On her retorn from Cairo, Mme Hading will give two more psrformancM, on Monday end Tuesday, 26th end 27th iost., respectively.

div.p: House of Commons —Sir E Grey, replying to Mr. Rutherford, said that Lord Cromer was examining the question of amending the Kbe-divial decree establishing a*pe ill tribonal fjr offences against British officers and soldiers. Until a definite decision had boon arrived at, he conld make no statement, hot Mr. Rutherford's suggestion to confine the scope of tho tribunal tffeicee against offioers and soldiers whon not engsgrd in the exeontion of their doty would be borne in miod. div.head: TURKEY AND GREAT BRITAIN.
THE NEW RAILWAY TRADE.
(FROM A CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: As railroad enterprise io Asiatio Torkey comot more Ind more into public view, spocial interest attaches to the conorssion just granted to the only British railway company to increase its mileage. The story of tbe Smyrna-Aidin Railway is in no small degree too history of the last fif-y years of British d'plnmatio in licence at Constantinople. Initiated in 1856, just after the olcse of the Crimean War, and completed to its prosent mileage in 1886, ita owners bave had to wait until 1906 lor permission to proceed with a long desired exteo-gion. Its early story is that of rhynOM of British capital at tbo ootset, failure to com-plete within tho time-limit, indulgent delays granted by the Turkish Government—the mileage of the original concession being ultimately opened in 1804—and then moch petitioning and piecemeal permissions to extead, until the present railhead was reached at Dinoir, 230 miles sooth end east of Smyrna. Certainly British irflnence with the Sublime Forte bas not been paramount sinoe the eighties, and a revival thereof, or even en eppa- J rent revival, ia not unsatisfactory. In tho otfier prospect, namely, the rapid opening up of Àsiatio Turkey by the civilising Iron Horse, the new concession plays a definite and important part. The Smyrna-Aidin is largely an egrionl, tarai line, {t taps tfie rich fruit and oereal prodnoing valleys of the Oayster and Meander rivera, which, with their tributaries, water much of the eonth western oorner ol Asia Minor. Inoloding the chief port of the Ottoman Umpire, tho distriot served today polatod as tûÿ ni its slss io the Soltan'e domintOLe, hot the passenger tisffio remains a minor feature of the railway. The goods trsffi-, however, shows the following respectable fignres for the latest annual retnrn : Goods, 150,000 tuns .minerals, IS.fOO tons ; live stock, 75,000 head. Leaving Smyrna, tho line roos south and east a distanoe of 80 miles to Aldin, pa-t ancient Ephesus, this being the original conoession, out pie ted io 1866. From Aidin, ihieh is oo the north and right bank of the Meander valley, the track continue; fast wards op the Meander val'py to Sereikeui a further CO miif>, opened in 1882 ; thenco, st(U easterly, it passes the ancient Laodioea and reaches railhead at Dineir, 90 miles fiom Seraikeni, and 230 from Smyrna. The whole joorney can be done in six bonrc. (noludiug branrhe», notably that up tbo Cayater valley Tireh. 3o miles long, the whole system covers 321 mile*. Apart from the as yet iosigoificaut mineral traffio the proffoae carried obneiata chiefly o( oereals and dried figs. Of the oereals, barley attains the greatest bulk, the Meandor valley producing a malting barley of the highest quality. Tub dried fig cultore has no, rival in any part of tfie world. The special tree providing this on'que indastry would appear to be indigenous to a distriot about 100 miles Iqug rgst and west between ffiitakohe and Ayasolouk, and 30 miles wide. Californian and other fig growers bave io vaio tried to aoolimatise the Meander plant, but a, parent)/ after a few years its spocial qualities are entirely lost on alien soil. It is here that the Smyrua-Aidin bas justified the confldence of its promoters, and ren-dored real benefits to the distriot—for the line seen a fivefold increase in the local fig-ouhore.lt bas served the Ottoman Gover.qieql also, the tithe revenue of the district havtna eased by some si»ty per oen»., owing the faciliter for-bringing the peasants' prodnoe the great Smyrna market. And when, under pressure horn the European Powers, the Porte radically alters its onerous, or almost prohibitive mining laws, there is little donbt that the Smyrna-Aidin Railway will still further augment the prosperity of the region it travel sw. Emery and manganese at p-esent claim the lion's share of the minorai trsffie, bot lead, plrmbago, ironstone granite, and white marble, and the precious metals are in eridence In the distriot The new-Imporial Irade sanctions the rxten-m of the line sooth and sontb-east from Dineir Lakes Buldnr and Egerdir ; in all 60 miles of traelr. The former lake is about twelve miles lang by tbrre wide, end Lake Bgerdir, handsome sheet of water, thirty miles north and south, by ten io its widest part. The fine cereal country eonntinoee along the line of the exteosioo, and well to both north >nd sooth of it, the Saltan himsell having chifliks, or farms, in the vicinity of Lake Bgerdir. Tbe company petitioned for the right steamers on Bgerdir 'from railhead at n^h-western extremity, in brder to tap the rich coçbt'y aronniT the northern -shores of'thalA^ bot the Iradé grants onl^*'no ||hird party rights" as bêtween tfie Company and the t/ttoman QovernmAt., A^much more smbitkios petition,namely, for an extension ipe santh' from Bgerdir to Aaaliefoo the Gulf oY tk^at name, a,farther sixty mileh-bas algo received n» betzer rpsponae then "no phird party rights ; in tjie fnture,alone willgliialo.e wluth-jf tluj _ impany*' oy tbo 'Turli-n *Treajinry will 6ep-neer theje quige obvion? noeds-cf cJmtooni-—A glance at the imp will «fiiw tbefposit:on*tf't^e Orff of Adalia »vritb'regard Bgerdir fid Smyrna* and bow wq entér upon '^trateg'u ooosidfiatiiye of great importance wbAt onnteniplatin^the Aluikfog op of Adalia with fSmyfta ^y a Briti.h bnilt and British-1 owned railroad. Ptft British enterprise bss , M- 83 rivals io tbia part of the world whose opposition hastitherto been serions and'kpataioed. Our status io the Levant, moreover, ooold not ( fail to be affected by Golf ol Adalia. Bat whatever opposition the direotore of the Bmyrne-Aidin Railway have had to en- Fri. 80 aontor during the sixteen years in which their petition for extension rights has been ignored, has been overcome, at loast, to the extent of the new Iradé, by British diplomatic assistance at Constantinople. 1 bad almost writ ton insistence, bat fur that I bave no wanant. It is, however, an open socret that oor Ambassador, Sir Nicholas O'Conor, bss urged the compsny's claims with tbe Sob-lime Porte. That his assistance has boon snocessfnl ia one of the most interesting features of the new conoession, for we have heard only too moch of diplomstio iodiflereooe supporting tho fioahoial enterprises of British subjects in the Turkish Empire. I', is, porbaps, to this apathy we owe the fact that the Smyrna-Aidin ia to day the only British-owned railway in Asiatio Tnrkoy- hree others having lapsed into German hands, and the Haifa-Damatont line having reverted to the Uttomao Government after vain eflorta on the part of the British concessionaire to finance tho undertaking. Naturally London capitalists, not immediately interested in Turkey, bave onntinnod to look askanoe at Anglo-Torki h propositions, however rosy. Popularly, all Turkish vonturos aro considered unsafe.' Popularly, it ia held that no Britirh Government will evor lend strong diplomatic action to its nationals. Much less ooold the British Foreign Office beexpeoted to "demand" a raw ooocession for a railway, a canal, a bridge, or what not Therefore, there ia no ex«ggeratioo affirming that diplomatic aaaistaooe in this long igoored petition of tho Smyrna Aidio Company ia ominontly oheering. And it has another aspect The Porte ia more likely to grant a conoession, if thereby political advantages will obviously accrue ; end in this oase probably the Turkish Government cbrxe ita own moment for showing complacency to the British Ambaa^Q^ Finally, tbe Smyrna-Aidin extension may bo regarded io its relation to Gorman railway aotivitios in Asiatio To i key- U it no sooret ! that Qerma.n diplomacy has been largely in-^trumenfal in blocking the compauy'g petition. A powerful German financial group, headed by tho Dcutacbo Bank, has been notoriously engaged in engineering the' Anatolian railway system and its ambitions extension, the great Baghdad Railway, to the Persian Galf, and has considered it part of ita busjneaa to ornah or control all line» working inland from the Æcean gnd Levantine littorals. More snccoss-fnl than the Smyrna-Cassaba and tho Moraine-Adana Railways, the 8myrna-Aidiu has withstood thia German control, and has, so to speak, stolen a valoablo prize ont of the lion's den at a crooial moment. For tho new trade, if it has not granted tho whole British claim, suocessfolly blocks German penetration to the Levantine coast within 25 miles east of Adalia, and at Adalfa them are facilities for the ooi.qtrootlon of a useful port and barbonr, which shall tap the hinterland of the Golf better than Smyrna on the north west Meriioa on the east. Thns it is obvions that the Sultan bss resisted German inflnence this once for many years. Bnt this may not neoes-sarily imply that British ioflooooe is costing German iofinence at Constaotinrp'e, bot it oertaloly indicates an improvement in Anglo-Torkish relations, and perhaps a new ontlook upon our Interests in the Near But Tarkiih diplomacy is, of coarse, not the least skilfol of dl seboole, bot it probably never loses sight of one consideration which is common gossip on the Bosphirns—tbe enlightened Turk looks Great Britain as the rock oo whiob to 1 the last resort, in ca;q (J real trouble.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905

div.head: Dinneford's Magnesia
